data.metadata_text: Climate Change: Agrifood systems emissions / Emissions from Livestock - Metadata
https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/GLE/metadata
Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)
Statistics Division (ESS), Environment Statistics team
Viale delle Terme di Caracalla, 00153 Rome, Italy
faostat@fao.org

The FAOSTAT domain Emissions from Livestock contains the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions originating from livestock rearing. The domain disseminates total methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions originating from livestock-related processes. Detailed emissions are also disseminated from 1) Enteric fermentation: the CH4 emissions produced from enteric fermentation processes in the digestive systems of ruminants and to a lesser extent of non-ruminants; 2) Manure left on pasture: the N2O emissions originated from the nitrogen in manure left by grazing livestock on pasture; c) Manure management: the CH4 and N2O emissions originating from aerobic and anaerobic processes of manure decomposition; d) Manure applied to soils: the N2O emissions originated from soils applications of manure. The FAOSTAT emissions database is computed following Tier 1 IPCC 2006 Guidelines for National GHG Inventories vol. 4, ch. 10 and 11 (http://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/vol4.html).GHG emissions are provided by country, regions and special groups, with global coverage, relative to the period 1961-present (with annual updates) and with projections for 2030 and 2050, expressed in units of kilotonnes of gas by livestock species (asses, buffaloes, camels, cattle (dairy and non-dairy), goats, horses, llamas, mules, sheep, swine (breeding and market)) and relevant species aggregates (all animals, camels and llamas, cattle, mules and asses, sheep and goats, swine). This FAOSTAT domain also disseminates the activity data and emissions reported by countries to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Emission data are sourced directly from the UNFCCC data portal or from Biennial Update Reports (BURs). UNFCCC data are disseminated in FAOSTAT with permission, formalized via a FAO-UNFCCC Memorandum of Understanding. The IPCC (2019) Guidelines indicate the FAOSTAT database as a useful tool for NGHGI QA/QC processes and validation of both activity data and emissions estimates.
Agrifood systems emissions
Annual N20 and CH4 emissions originated from livestock rearing processes. A detailed Methodological Note is available in the 'Related documents' section of the FAOSTAT domain.
Reference area: World. Data are available for 201 countries and territories (FAO TIER I) | Code - reference area: FAOSTAT, M49, ISO2 and ISO3 (https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#definitions).
Time coverage: 1961-2021 | Periodicity: Yearly
Not Applicable

GHG emissions: direct, indirect and N20 emissions (kt); CH4 emissions (kt). Activity data: Stocks (number of animals); Manure management (manure treated, N content in kg); Manure left on pasture (N content in kg); Manure left on pasture that leaches (N content in kg); Manure left on pasture that volatilises (N content in kg); Manure applied to soils (N content in kg); Manure applied to soils that leaches (N content in kg); Manure applied to soils thatvolatilises (N content in kg).
Calendar Year for the emissions estimates.

Article I of FAO constitution states "The Organization shall collect, analyse, interpret and disseminate information relating to nutrition, food and agriculture (the term “agriculture” and its derivatives includes forestry, fisheries and aquaculture). The first session of the FAO Conference in 1945 provided the rationale: “If FAO is to carry out its work successfully it will need to know where and why hunger and malnutrition exist, what forms they take, and how widespread they are. Such data will serve as a basis for making plans, determining the efficacy of measures used, and measuring progress from time to time.”

Data sharing in FAOSTAT is regulated by the FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework (https://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf) in application of the " Principles governing international statistical activities on Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics" (http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/statorg/Principles_stat_activities/principles_stat_activities.pdf).

FAO Statistical Quality Assurance Framework, 2014, Principle 10: "All data subject to national confidentiality policies (e.g. concerning people and legal entities, or small aggregates) are kept strictly confidential, and are used exclusively for statistical purposes, or for purposes mandated by legislation."

All data subject to national confidentiality policies (e.g. concerning peopleand legal entities, or small aggregates) are kept strictly confidential, and re-used exclusively for statistical purposes, or for purposes mandated by legislation. (See the FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework https://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf).
No confidential data
Data are released once a year or when they are available.
https://fenixservices.fao.org/faostat/static/releasecalendar/Default.aspx

User access: User data access in FAOSTAT is regulated by the FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework (https://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf) in application of the " Principles governing international statistical activities on Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics" (http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/statorg/Principles_stat_activities/principles_stat_activities.pdf). | Terms of use: https://www.fao.org/contact-us/terms/db-terms-of-use/en/ This work is made available under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 IGO license (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO; https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/igo). In addition to this license, some database specific terms of use are listed: Terms of Use of Datasets.
Frequency of dissemination: Yearly
Ad-hoc news releases.

Tubiello, F.N. 2019. Greenhouse Gas Emissions Due to Agriculture. In: Ferranti, P., Berry, E.M., Anderson, J.R. (Eds.), Encyclopedia of Food Security and Sustainability, vol. 1, pp. 196–205. Elsevier. ISBN: 9780128126875.FAO. 2020. Livestock and environment statistics: manure and greenhouse gas emissions. Global, regional and country trends, 1990–2018. FAOSTAT Analytical Brief Series No. 14. Rome.
FAOSTAT Emissions database, publicly available from: https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/GLE
No micro data
A complete methodological note is available under the ' Related Documents'  section of this domain.

The main users are FAO analysts, other international organizations, national governments, research institutes and universities, journalists and general public. The IPCC Guidelines (2019) indicate the FAOSTAT database as a useful tool for NGHGI QA/QC processes and validation of both activity data and emissions estimates.
Feedback from users are routinely recorded. The FAOSTAT User Consultation took place during April-December 2018. https://www.fao.org/3/ca7239en/ca7239en.pdf
Completeness of emission estimates reflects completeness of  activity data, i.e. animal stocks by species, year and country. Aggregated emission estimates necessarily reflect this.

Uncertainties in estimates of GHG emissions are due to uncertainties in emission factors and activity data. They may be related to, inter alia, natural variability, partitioning fractions, lack of spatial or temporal coverage, spatial aggregation. In the case of enteric fermentation, more detailed information is available in the IPCC guidelines: IPCC, 2006: Vol. 4, Ch. 10, Section 10.3.4. For the manure left on pasture more detailed information is available in the IPCC guidelines (IPCC, 2006: Vol.4, Ch. 11, Section 11.2.1.4 for direct emissions, and Section 11.2.2.4 for indirect emissions). In the case of manure management, more detailed information is available in the IPCC guidelines (IPCC, 2006: Vol. 4, Ch. 10, Section 10.5.5); For the manure applied to soil, more detailed information is available in the guidelines (IPCC, 2006: Vol.4, Ch. 11, Section 11.2.1.4 for direct emissions, and Section 11.2.2.4 for indirect emissions).
In case revised activity data or IPCC methodologies become available, revision of FAOSTAT emissions is reflected in the database.
Revised data are disseminated yearly.
For emission estimates: Average production time for data in the FAOSTAT emission database is approximately six months. For source data: production data on stock numbers are released yearly.
The whole dataset is released according to the established released calendar or at the latest within one or two weeks after the due date.
Fairly good comparability of emission estimates at global level, reflecting comparability of source data.
Fairly good comparability in the short to medium terms.
Coherence - cross domain: Cross domain coherence is regularly checked throught QA/QC internal processes. | Coherence - internal: Internal data coherence is checked routinely through QA/QC processes.

For emission estimates: classification follows the IPCC 2006 Guidelines, Vol.4, Ch. 2 and 4 (http://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/vol4.html).For source data (activity data): FAO CPC classification.

FAOSTAT Emissions data are computed based on Activity Data collected from countries through a yearly questionnaire and available in the FAOSTAT domain Crops and Livestock products: https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/QCL

data.metadata_text: Activity data harvested from the FAOSTAT domain Crops and Livestock products https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/QCL
QA/QC procedures are in place to check for and correct transmission errors, data consistency and completeness.
Based on the availability of activity data.
Standard FAOSTAT regional aggregates.
No adjustments.
No imputation.

Quality documentation: For the emission estimates:CHAR(13)CHAR(10)No quality report is available. However, quality assessment (12.2), relevance(13), accuracy (14), timeliness (15), as well as comparability (16) and coherence (17) altogether indicate a fair quality of estimates, compatibly with the underlying Tier 1 IPCC methodology applied.CHAR(13)CHAR(10)CHAR(13)CHAR(10)For source data (activity data):CHAR(13)CHAR(10)https://www.fao.org/forestry/fra/en/. | Quality assurance: The FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework (https://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf).

For emission estimates: A peer-review process was launched (details of results in https://www.fao.org/climatechange/35293-0586769eafd852c772743b5e92ca84868.pdf ). Further to this, results were presented in a series of peer-reviewed publications (links at: https://www.fao.org/climatechange/micca/ghg/en including the IPCC Fifth Assessment Report (http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter11.pdf). For source data (see 20.1): No unitary quality assessment is available.

The FAOSTAT Emissions database is developed and maintained by the FAO Statistics Division. Initial support was kindly provided by Norway and Germany under Trust Funds GCP/GLO/286/GER and GCP/GLO/325/NOR. Support by UNFCCC in information sharing and facilitation of data access is also graciously acknowledged.
